Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Chongqing, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Chongqing, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a latent compartment E is included for individuals who are infected but not yet able to spread the virus. This is biologically realistic as COVID-19 can have an incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be infectious. It is important to differentiate between the latent period, the time from infection to being infectious, and the incubation period, the time from infection to the onset of symptoms. For SARS, individuals become infectious around two days after symptoms appear. In the case of COVID-19, evidence suggests that individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the length of the latent period is not well understood. While the SEIR model is more realistic biologically than the SIR model, it does have the drawback of requiring parameters for the latent period and initial latent population. The transfer diagrams and model parameters are provided in figures and tables. Both models assume negligible deaths in the S, E, and I compartments during the prediction period. The differential equations for each model are given. Data calibration for both models relies on newly confirmed cases and does not consider deaths in the R compartment.

post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body.Here we distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectivity, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to onset of symptoms for COVID-19. In the case of SARS, individuals become infectious two days after symptoms appear (WHO, 2003), making the SARS latent period longer than the incubation period. Research has shown that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms (Bai et al., 2020), but the duration of the latent period remains uncertain. The SEIR model offers greater biological realism compared to the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Figures and tables illustrating the transfer diagrams and model parameters can be found in Fig. 1 and Table 1 and Table 2, respectively. It is assumed in both models that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible within the model's time frame (4 months). Given that data on newly confirmed cases is used for calibration, the death rate in the R compartment has no impact on model fitting. The differential equations for each model are provided above. Data used for calibration includes newly confirmed cases in Huangshi from January 21 to February 4, 2020, sourced from official reports by the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China.

3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model

We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious.

3.1. The models

In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, compartment I denotes the infectious population, and
post_context:
. 

In the SEIR model, individuals who are infected but not yet infectious are represented in the latent compartment E. This latency is based on the realistic incubation period of up to 14 days for COVID-19, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious as the virus is incubating in the body. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, from infection to symptom onset. Whereas individuals infected with SARS become infectious around two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that COVID-19 patients can spread the virus before showing symptoms. While the SEIR model is more biologically accurate than the SIR model, it requires additional parameters such as the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the time frame of predictions. The differential equations for each model are provided above. Model calibration is based on newly confirmed cases data.

Following the mayor of Shanghai's announcement at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million individuals had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population in Shanghai on January 19 to be approximately 6 million. We utilized the same uniform distributions for the initial parameters in both models, detailed in Tables 1 and 2. Using an affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, posterior distributions for estimated parameters were generated. Best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained from these posterior distributions, with results presented in Table 1 for the SIR model and Table 2 for the SEIR model. Through comparison of the calibration results, we calculated the corrected Akaike Information Criterion AICc for both models to be 174 and 186, respectively. The substantial difference (D = 12) indicates that the SEIR model may result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model. As a result, our further analysis will focus on the SIR model. Additionally, our calibration of the SIR model revealed a linkage between the transmission rate (b) and diagnosis rate (r), as illustrated in Figure 2.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Utilizing a variety of sources, such as technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be beneficial for model calibration. However, this can be challenging when dealing with outbreaks of unknown pathogens happening in real time, like SARS in 2003 or the current COVID-19 pandemic. To address this difficulty, improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms can be employed to narrow the often wide confidence or credible intervals. Our approach utilized Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to effectively achieve this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Chongqing were generated by sampling the posterior distribution to create prediction intervals. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals, with the Bayesian inference informed by newly confirmed cases from official reports between January 21 and February 4, 2020. These predictions reflect the situation during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Chongqing, prior to additional control measures implemented after February 7, 2020. The projections provide an estimation of how the epidemic in Chongqing might have progressed if further control measures had not been put in place. Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the projected peak time and estimated values for the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Chongqing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimates, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the total number of peak cases would be around 120,000 and the epidemic in Chongqing would likely not be resolved before mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding based on acuity levels. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases as outlined in Table 1, with non-critical cases assumed to recover and critical cases having a chance of recovery or death, with death probability increasing with age (Table 2). Transmission occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual with a probability of β, where a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7 for a well-mixed population with 20 contacts per day. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was chosen based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,

Interventions like physical distancing can alter the transmission factor, denoted as β. This is approximated by two stages of viral load, with the high stage lasting for 30% of the infectious period or 4 days, whichever is shorter. Transmission of the virus occurs when susceptible individuals interact with infectious ones, with a probability of transmission represented by β. author: enrique
pre_context:
Therefore, it is important for users to adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. The value of β is influenced by the inclusion of realistic network structures, such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts. Transmission probabilities default to approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1. These values were selected based on time-use surveys and studies of known contact types to maintain a mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, transmission events are estimated to occur in households (30%), workplaces (25%), schools (15%), and the community (30%). The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, variability in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectivity over time is accounted for by allowing individual differences in viral load.

Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context:
, which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Olympia state and Washington.

The daily viral load determines the adjustment of the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual each day. Fig 2 illustrates the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the context, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence regarding whether transmission is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we include a parameter that can be changed based on the specific modeling application or context, acknowledging that some studies have suggested much lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
